video.title: Ratchet and Clank: Rift Apart (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
You may recall my first and only experience
with Ratchet and Clank was playing that one

on the PS4 that was tying in with the movie,
and which made me go &quot;Hm, is that the smell

of distended rectum, or has this franchise
gone completely up itself?&quot;

Always an occupational hazard when a series
goes on too long, runs out of new territory

to explore and instead decides to settle down
and curl up inside its own bum.

But what an excellent setting of tone for
the latest one, Ratchet and Clank: Rift Apart.

Incidentally, speaking of bums, whatever happened
to the tradition of Ratchet and Clank games

having slightly risque subtitles like Going
Commando or Up Your Arsenal in the grand Dreamworks

movies Grabbed by the Ghoulies stealth joke
for the mums and dads tradition?

Suppose we&#39;re above that kind of cheeky fun
these days, aren&#39;t we, Sony.

Probably got nixed by someone in marketing
whose only experience with comedy is having

had it patiently explained to them at a mandatory
seminar.

I&#39;m trying to think of ways the title &quot;Rift
Apart&quot; could apply to bums but all the possibilities
make me feel uncomfortable.

CORRECTION: (ahem) While rewatching this video
prior to final upload, it occurred to me that

&quot;rift apart&quot; might be intended as a sort of
pseudo-spoonerism for &quot;ripped a fart.&quot;

Which would be a bum joke and if that was
intentional I hereby retract the preceding

complaint about the subtitle not being a bum
joke.

I repeat, Ratchet and Clank&#39;s issues may not
presently be for want of bum jokes.
We now resume your snarky internet video.

It&#39;s called Rift Apart because the plot deals
with the eponymous duo getting transported

to another dimension hauntingly similar to
their own with identical game mechanics but

where they never got together and therefore
everything is wrong and bad.

Which is just about the only plot left that
a franchise that has gotten up itself can do.

When the heroes have won too many times and
the villains humiliated too often to be a

credible threat it&#39;s time to play the What
If card.

It&#39;s like what happened to superhero comics
after they officially ran out of ideas circa

1975 and every story since has just been one
race after another to restore the status quo,

in which Spider-Man is poor and miserable
and Batman is rich and miserable, and as of

course we recently learned, unadventurous
in the bedroom.

So in the new dimension our heroes get trapped
in, the local versions of Ratchet and Clank

- girl versions no less, the fan fiction community
will be abuzz with madly oscillating fists

tonight - never met or became partners, and
so girl Ratchet and girl Clank getting together

is the fucking final puzzle piece required
to win the day and finally correct their deviant existence.

See, there&#39;s something terribly flimsy about
the setting of Ratchet and Clank.

Which might be because it one hundred percent
pivots around the relationship between a space
cat and his fucking roomba.

On the one hand it&#39;s got this grand space
opera interplanetary scope but it also seems
so weirdly underpopulated.

It&#39;s like each planet only has one actual
character on it and ten million copy pasted

generic locals whose job is to run around
screaming every time something explodes.

And a lot of the plot feels like one contrived
excuse to go to a new planet after another.
We need to get a magic crystal.

Let&#39;s go to the magic crystal planet where
they&#39;re mined from.
Oh no, our magic crystal shattered.

Well we&#39;re on the magic crystal planet, couldn&#39;t
we just get another one?

No! Now we must go to the fixing things planet,
and enlist the legendary fixer of things.
This is literally what happens at one point.

It&#39;s like someone casually brings up this
fixer dude and suddenly that&#39;s the only imaginable

solution to a problem that only calls for
half an hour&#39;s work and a pritt stick.

Then we go to the fixer planet and have to
fight a fucking giant robot out of nowhere

until I guess the sequence runs out of set
pieces and we abruptly stop fighting the giant robot.
&quot;Oh sorry, thought you were someone else.
Here&#39;s your fixed crystal.
Plot tangent over.&quot;
As for the gameplay, it&#39;s Ratchet and Clank.

You switch between playing Ratchet Classic
and Girl Ratchet, whose actual name is Rivet,

and I tell you that now before I give into
my sudden extremely shameful impulse to refer
to her as &quot;snatchet.&quot;

And the opportunity to mix the gameplay up
with a new playable character was missed like

Catwoman&#39;s unfulfilled G-spot because they
both play exactly the same.

In fact, when one of them gets a new gadget
or weapon the other one automatically has

it as well without them even having to meet,
possibly thanks to Space Dropbox.

So it&#39;s mostly more of the same, the usual
rail grinding, box smashing, pew pew combat

and levelling up your favourite weapons until
they become super powerful and then never

fucking using them again because your dog
turd on a stick needs levelling up and you
don&#39;t want to waste the XP.

The only significant addition to core gameplay
is a quick dodge button, which I seem to remember

saying the last game could have done with
when the combat got intense, so again it&#39;s
nice to know I still have that power.

For my next trick, I will command Sony to
cluck like a chicken and release Bloodborne
on Steam for fuck&#39;s sake.

Otherwise it&#39;s more of that very PS2-esque
Ratchet and Clank gameplay that hasn&#39;t changed

much since the first racily subtitled sequel,
but you know what, no bad thing, say I.

In a world where it seems like every AAA franchise
is inexorably creeping towards the universal

Jiminy Cockthroat model like blobs of hairy
cum towards a prison shower drain it&#39;s actually

nice to see something resisting the pull and
sticking with what works.

And honestly as up itself as the story has
gotten it is sort of impressive that it&#39;s

still maintaining the same continuity after
all this time and has only had a slight dalliance
with rebooting.
I just find the characters really boring.

It&#39;s a ways into the game before Ratchet and
Rivet meet up in person and since being the

last member of his species is Ratchet&#39;s only
remaining interesting character trait their
eventual meeting is hyped up with some significance.

I mean, these two are pretty much gonna have
to smash at some point if only for the sake
of scientific enquiry.

But then they do meet and it&#39;s like watching
two teenagers being forced to hang out together

at a barbecue because their parents are part
of the same swinger&#39;s club.

And meanwhile basically every other character
is &quot;comedy person who gets flustered and talks
too much.&quot;

A character archetype that to my mind should
be sealed in the nearest Borderlands game
and chained to the ocean floor.

So that&#39;s Ratchet and Clank: Rift Apart, generally
inoffensive but hardly pushing the envelope,
more prodding the post-it note, really.

I apologise for the abject blandness of this
take.
And also for the lateness of this review.

It would have come out sooner if we&#39;d gotten
a review code before the release date but

Sony wouldn&#39;t give us one when they found
out what it was for.

They said that, quote, &quot;Given the tone of
that coverage, we&#39;d prefer you secure your
own code.&quot;

From where, Sony, the fucking dumpster outside
your office?

I don&#39;t normally give you these cheeky little
glances behind the beef curtains but I mean, really.

I guess we all knew publishers want to dictate
the content of reviews, hence those review

guides they keep sending us that read like
a timid schoolchild asking to please not be

kicked in these specific sensitive areas,
but I didn&#39;t expect them to just come out
and admit it.
What&#39;s your problem with my &quot;tone,&quot; Sony?
You didn&#39;t know I&#39;d make the &quot;snatchet&quot; joke.
